pull.title: doc: clarify CRollingBloomFilter size estimate
pull.body:
Based on #19130, this change improves the comment for `CRollingBloomFilter` in `bloom.h`:

- Give examples to illustrate the heuristic "1.8 bytes per element per factor 0.1 of false positive rate"
- Add some Python code which can be copy/pasted for convenient filter size calculation (in an interpreter)
- Reconcile the newly added code with the existing approximation

events.body:
ACK `01d14f2`

I tested this by being new to bitcoin and having only a high-level understanding of bloom filters. The commit made the trade-off between the acceptable false positive rate and memory footprint easy to understand. A couple optional nits below.

rename.from: doc: make it easier to work out size of bloom filter

issue.title: doc: make it easier to work out size of bloom filter
issue.body: I've manually traced through the bloom filter code to work out how big a filter ends up being a few times now; this just adds some python code as a comment so it's easy to do that by cutting and pasting into an interpreter instead.

issue.title: Backport bloom filter improvements
issue.body:
Cherry-picked from the following upstream PRs:

- bitcoin/bitcoin#7113
- bitcoin/bitcoin#7818
  - Only the second commit (to resolve conflicts).
- bitcoin/bitcoin#7934
- bitcoin/bitcoin#8655
  - Partial backport to help resolve conflicts.
- bitcoin/bitcoin#9060
- bitcoin/bitcoin#9223
- bitcoin/bitcoin#9644
  - Partial backport to help resolve conflicts.
- bitcoin/bitcoin#9916
- bitcoin/bitcoin#9750
- bitcoin/bitcoin#13176
- bitcoin/bitcoin#13948
- bitcoin/bitcoin#16073
- bitcoin/bitcoin#18670
- bitcoin/bitcoin#18806
  - Reveals upstream's covert fix for CVE-2013-5700.
- bitcoin/bitcoin#19968

labels.name: C-upstream-port
labels.description: Category: Changes that are ported from the Bitcoin Core codebase.

labels.name: I-dos
labels.description: Problems and improvements with respect to Denial-of-Service.

labels.name: safe-to-build
labels.description: Used to send PR to prod CI environment

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -94,7 +94,26 @@ class CBloomFilter
  * insert()'ed ... but may also return true for items that were not inserted.
  *
  * It needs around 1.8 bytes per element per factor 0.1 of false positive rate.
- * (More accurately: 3/(log(256)*log(2)) * log(1/fpRate) * nElements bytes)
+ * e.g. for 1000 elements, we'd need:
+ *     ~1800 bytes for a false positive rate of 0.1
+ *     ~3600 bytes for a false positive rate of 0.01
+ *     ~5400 bytes for a false positive rate of 0.001
+ *
+ * This Python code calculates the exact filter size in bytes:
+
+import math
+def filterbytes(nel, fprate):
+    logfp = math.log(fprate)
+    nhash = max(1, min(round(logfp/math.log(0.5)), 50))
+    nfilbits = math.ceil(-1.0*nhash*(3*int((nel+1)/2)) / math.log(1.0 - math.exp(logfp / nhash)))
+    return (nfilbits+63)/64*2*8
+
+ * If we make these assumptions:
comments.body: Nit: I found these next 6 lines added complexity to something that was very clear thus far. Do you think the simpler formula makes it easier to reason about the size of the bloom filter?

comments.body: Nit: Maybe add "Lower tolerance for false positives increases the size of the bloom filter manifesting a trade-off between memory and compute (in the case of a false positive)."

comments.body:
How does this render on doxygen? If it is markdown style you'd likely want to quote an inline script using triple-backquotes.

TBH I'm not sure the python script adds much in the first place. Sometimes a simple but good-enough approximation is better for documentation purposes. Is this level of precision necessary?

(edit: whoops, didn't mean to click the resolve conversation button)

comments.body: Yeah, fair question @laanwj . I picked this up from the "up for grabs" #19130 but I could go either wayif we think the extra precision doesn't really help then we can close this PR.

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -94,7 +94,26 @@ class CBloomFilter
  * insert()'ed ... but may also return true for items that were not inserted.
  *
  * It needs around 1.8 bytes per element per factor 0.1 of false positive rate.
- * (More accurately: 3/(log(256)*log(2)) * log(1/fpRate) * nElements bytes)
+ * e.g. for 1000 elements, we'd need:
+ *     ~1800 bytes for a false positive rate of 0.1
+ *     ~3600 bytes for a false positive rate of 0.01
+ *     ~5400 bytes for a false positive rate of 0.001

+ * This Python code calculates the exact filter size in bytes:
+
+import math
+def filterbytes(nel, fprate):
+    logfp = math.log(fprate)
+    nhash = max(1, min(round(logfp/math.log(0.5)), 50))
+    nfilbits = math.ceil(-1.0*nhash*(3*int((nel+1)/2)) / math.log(1.0 - math.exp(logfp / nhash)))
+    return (nfilbits+63)/64*2*8
+
+ * If we make these assumptions:
comments.body:
See my comment: https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/19130#issuecomment-637176259

Given how accurate the formula is in all reasonable cases (at most 0.115% off, and usually much less), I don't think it's worth including the code.

The rest of the PR seems useful, though.

comments.body: Ooh, didn't know about doxygen use before, thanks for the reminder! The formatting should be reasonable now:
